meanings.def: weighing a lot; difficult to lift or move
examples: a heavy weight/load
She was struggling with a heavy suitcase.
My brother is much heavier than me.
He tried to push the heavy door open.
How heavy is it (= how much does it weigh)?
(especially North American English) Many young people today are too heavy (= fat).
(figurative) Her father carried a heavy burden of responsibility.
The bottles of wine made the bag even heavier.
You're getting too heavy to carry!
She felt her eyelids growing heavy (= she was getting sleepy).

meanings.def: more or worse than usual in amount, degree, etc.
examples: the noise of heavy traffic
heavy rain/rainfall/snow
the effects of heavy drinking
There was heavy fighting in the capital last night.
The British suffered heavy losses in the battle.
His unit came under heavy fire from insurgents.
The penalty for speeding can be a heavy fine.
She spoke with heavy irony.

meanings.def: doing the thing mentioned more, or more deeply, than usual
examples: a heavy drinker/smoker
a heavy sleeper

meanings.def: large and solid
examples: big, dark rooms full of heavy furniture
He was tall and strong, with heavy features.

meanings.def: thick
examples: heavy curtains
a heavy coat

meanings.def: full of or loaded with something
examples: trees heavy with apples
The air was heavy with the scent of flowers.
His voice was heavy with sarcasm.
She was heavy with child (= pregnant).

meanings.def: large and powerful
examples: a wide range of engines and heavy machinery/equipment
heavy lorries/trucks

meanings.def: involving a lot of work or activity; very busy
examples: a heavy schedule
She'd had a heavy day.

meanings.def: hard, especially because it requires a lot of physical strength
examples: heavy lifting
A gardener comes in to do the heavy work for me.

meanings.def: falling or hitting something with a lot of force
examples: a heavy fall/blow

meanings.def: large in amount or very solid
examples: a heavy lunch/dinner/meal
Avoid heavy foods that are difficult to digest.

meanings.def: carrying heavy weapons
examples: the heavy infantry/cavalry

meanings.def: loud and deep
examples: heavy breathing
a heavy groan/sigh

meanings.def: using a lot of something
examples: Older cars are heavy on gas.
Don't go so heavy on the garlic.

meanings.def: serious; difficult to understand or enjoy
examples: We found the play very heavy.
The discussion got a little heavy.

meanings.def: dangerous because of big waves, etc.
examples: strong winds and heavy seas
The heavy Atlantic swells pounded the beach.

meanings.def: hot and without enough fresh air, in a way that feels unpleasant
examples: It's very heavy—I think there'll be a storm.

meanings.def: wet, sticky and difficult to dig or to move over
very strict and severe
examples: Don't be so heavy on her—it wasn't her fault.

meanings.def: to become very serious, because strong feelings are involved
examples: They started shouting at me. It got very heavy.
Then he got heavy and tried to kiss me.
Things were starting to get a bit heavy so I decided to leave.

meanings.def: to have a difficult problem that makes you worried or unhappy but that you have to deal with
examples: We all have our crosses to bear.

meanings.def: used to describe somebody/something that is difficult to deal with or understand
examples: She's a bit heavy going.
I found the course rather heavy going.

meanings.def: a way of doing something or of treating people that is much stronger and less sensitive than it needs to be
examples: the heavy hand of management

meanings.def: a very sad feeling
examples: She left her children behind with a heavy heart.

meanings.def: a group of strong, often violent people employed to do something such as protect somebody
a situation when people do not say anything, but feel embarrassed or uncomfortable
to seem to find something more difficult or complicated than it needs to be
examples: People in this country make such heavy weather of learning languages.

meanings.def: to have a bad effect on somebody/something; to cause a lot of damage, deaths, pain, etc.
examples: Illness had taken a heavy toll on her.
The recession is taking its toll on the housing markets.
The pressure of fame can take a terrible toll.

idioms.idiom: take a heavy toll (on somebody/something) | take its toll (on somebody/something)
idioms.def: to have a bad effect on somebody/something; to cause a lot of damage, deaths, pain, etc.
examples: Illness had taken a heavy toll on her.
The recession is taking its toll on the housing markets.
The pressure of fame can take a terrible toll.

meanings.def: a large strong man whose job is to protect a person or place, often using violence
examples: He lunged at the minister, but was soon pulled to the ground by a couple of heavies.

meanings.def: strong beer, especially bitter
examples: a pint of heavy

meanings.def: to be very easy to notice in a particular place in a way that is unpleasant
examples: Smoke lay heavy on the far side of the water.
Despair hangs heavy in the stifling air.

meanings.def: to cause somebody/something to feel uncomfortable or anxious
examples: The crime lay heavy on her conscience.
